Born and raised in Riverside IL, Chris jokes that he’s the Polish kid who cooks Italian. Today he’s the owner and head chef at The Bristol, which received the coveted Michelin Bib Gourmand Award. He is also an owner of another heralded Chicago restaurant, Balena. Chris and his wife Linnzie have two sons and are big fans of forming early healthy eating habits by creating baby foods using fresh produce and meats.

Chris' restaurants

The Bristol
Balena
Chef Pandel's recipe

spaghetti squash pancakes

start them early

You shouldn’t feel limited in what foods you introduce to your children. They don’t know any better. Whatever you feed them is what they know. To change any bad habits or patterns, start to introduce fruits in their oatmeal. Or maybe blueberries in their cereal. Go with a fresh approach and build from there.

Chris Pandel's food tip

The texture in farro is great for cold salads, and trail mix. Cook the dried grains, cool them, set them out overnight, and then mix in some peanuts, raisins, nuts, berries or whatever you have around.

spinach quinoa baby food

Cook the quinoa until it’s super soft and then put it in a food processor with some raw spinach. Cool it down in a few ice cube trays and store it. The cubes also make it super easy to reheat on the stove or in a microwave. Make a big batch and it will last for a week.

Q & A

Which Mariano’s do you shop?

We shop the Roscoe store in the city during the week and Arlington Heights when we visit (Chris’) parents on the weekend.

How do you plan your family meals?

Actually, we just wing it unless we have had a craving for something.

Who was your biggest cooking influence growing up?

Grandmother Adamaina is the best cook ever. She has to get the credit she is due.

How hard is it to be a successful chef in the city of Chicago?

I will let you know when I figure that out! It’s a tough job no matter what.

What’s your/her favorite style to cook at home?

We cook a ton of Asian and Latin American food at home.

What do you like about the Mariano’s International aisle?

What's not to like? From Eastern European to Southeast Asian it’s an incredibly diverse section of the store, which provides lots of inspiration to take your meals off of the beaten path.

What is your kids' favorite snack at home?

I’d say a sandwich on whole wheat with lots of veggies. A nice piece of fruit with some rice crackers will get the kids through the next few hours of school without a sugar rush/crash

How did you get into making baby food?

We had a baby. It just seems like a natural progression.

Is there an ingredient that would make a nice baby food on its own?

Babies like plain food, so anything that is fairly neutral will suffice. We have done everything from fruits and veggies to whole grains and oats

What surprising thing is in your fridge right now?

A carrot cake muffin!
